properties.areaDesc: Pickens, SC; Hart, GA; Anderson, SC
properties.headline: Flood Advisory issued February 11 at 5:25AM EST until February 11 at 11:30AM EST by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg SC
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Greenville-Spartanburg has issued a

* Flood Advisory for...
Hart County in northeastern Georgia...
Central Anderson County in Upstate South Carolina...
Pickens County in Upstate South Carolina...

* Until 1130 AM EST Tuesday.

* At 522 AM EST, Doppler radar and automated rain gauges indicated
rounds of moderate rainfall are returning to Anderson, Hart, and
Pickens counties after a quieter past 6 hours, when less than a
quarter inch of rainfall occurred.  The lighter rainfall allowed
streams to crest following widespread storm-total rainfall of 1-2
inches since 7am Monday morning.  However, latest radar trends
suggest an additional 0.50-1 inch of rainfall is possible over the
immediate 1-2 hours. This additional rainfall over saturated soils
will induce new runoff which will likely keep streams elevated and
cause nuisance flooding of low-lying areas to develop shortly.

* Additional rainfall of 1-2 inches is possible early Tuesday
morning through Tuesday afternoon.  This will exacerbate ongoing
flooding and may cause new flooding to develop.  This area may be
upgraded to a Flash Flood Warning if additional heavy
rainfall develops. Residents within low-lying areas, especially
adjacent to streams, are encouraged to stay weather aware and have
a way to receive NWS warnings.  Drivers are urged to obey all
barricades and avoid flooded roadways.

* Some locations that may experience flooding include...
Anderson, Easley, Clemson, Hartwell, Pickens, Homeland Park,
Powdersville, Central, Northlake and Pendleton.
properties.instruction:
Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the
dangers of flooding.

In hilly terrain there are hundreds of low water crossings which are
potentially dangerous in heavy rain. Do not attempt to cross flooded
roads. Turn around, dont drown.

If heavy rainfall continues, the advisory may be upgraded to a Flash
Flood Warning. People in flood prone areas, especially along creeks
and small streams, should prepare to move to higher ground quickly if
a Flash Flood Warning is issued.
